title: Sir Walter Barttelot, 1st Baronet
text:
Sir Walter Barttelot, 1st Baronet, (10 October 1820 – 2 February 1893) was a <a href="Conservative%20Party%20%28UK%29">Conservative Party</a> politician in the <a href="United%20Kingdom">United Kingdom</a> who served as <a href="Member%20of%20Parliament%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">Member of Parliament</a> for several constituencies.
Life.
A member of an ancient <a href="Sussex">Sussex</a> family, Barttelot was the son of George Barttelot and his wife Emma (née Woodbridge). He was educated at <a href="Rugby%20School">Rugby School</a> and then served in the <a href="1st%20Royal%20Dragoons">1st Royal Dragoons</a>, purchasing his <a href="Captain%20%28British%20Army%20and%20Royal%20Marines%29">captaincy</a> on 7 February 1845. After retirement from the army he raised the <a href="6th%20%28Petworth%29%20Sussex%20Rifle%20Volunteer%20Corps">6th (Petworth) Sussex Rifle Volunteer Corps</a> on 15 February 1860 and was promoted to <a href="Major%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">major</a> to command the <a href="2nd%20Administrative%20Battalion%2C%20Sussex%20Rifle%20Volunteer%20Corps">2nd Administrative Battalion, Sussex Rifle Volunteer Corps</a> on 26 April 1860. He continued to command the <a href="2nd%20Sussex%20Rifle%20Volunteers">2nd Sussex Rifle Volunteers</a> until he became its <a href="Colonel%20%28United%20Kingdom%29%23Honorary%20Colonel">Honorary Colonel</a> in 1882.
In December 1860 he was elected as a <a href="Member%20of%20Parliament">Member of Parliament</a> for <a href="West%20Sussex%20%28UK%20Parliament%20constituency%29">West Sussex</a>, which he served until 1885 when he became member for <a href="Horsham%20%28UK%20Parliament%20constituency%29">Horsham</a>, serving until his death. Horsham's Barttelot Road off the Brighton Road was named after him. Sussex Police Headquarters was located there and current photographs of Barttelot Road are featured (<a href="https%3A//web.archive.org/web/20121107223553/http%3A//www.hiddenhorsham.co.uk/25/25.htm">Hidden Horsham</a>). Barttelot was created a <a href="baronet">baronet</a>, of <a href="Stopham">Stopham</a> in the <a href="County%20of%20Sussex">County of Sussex</a>, on 14 June 1875, and made a <a href="Order%20of%20the%20Bath">Companion of the Order of the Bath</a> in 1880. In 1892 he was admitted to the <a href="Privy%20Council%20of%20the%20United%20Kingdom">Privy Council</a>.
He became a director of the <a href="London%2C%20Brighton%20and%20South%20Coast%20Railway">London, Brighton and South Coast Railway</a> in August 1864, and served as its chairman from April to July 1867.
Barttelot married firstly Harriet, daughter of Sir Christopher Musgrave, 9th Baronet, in 1852. They had two sons and five daughters, including <a href="Edith%20Sclater">Dame Edith Sclater</a>. After his first wife's death in 1863 he married secondly Margaret, daughter of Henry Boldero, in 1868. They had no children. Lady Barttelot died in January 1893. Barttelot survived her by only a few days and died in early February 1893, aged 72. He was succeeded in the baronetcy by his eldest son Walter.
